text: Patient: I don’t know. The last one I had was in June. Doctor: Okay, I think you are so I’m gonna give this to J____ so we can just get everything on one paper because I don’t want to lose track of your next injection either. So, your Lupron stays in the background, we fart around with all this. Patient: Well, I took that in, Lupron and then all this. Doctor: In June or August? Oh, do I give you the Lupron? Oh, I don’t, Patient: No, Dr___ I had went to him in August. Doctor: okay. That’s why I don’t know, got it, yep. Patient: And I go back I think it’s in March. He gave me a six month shot this time. Doctor: Perfect. So, we will do the scans. I will see you back after you do the scan so it might be a week or two tops and then we’ll have a plan. In the meantime, I will have J____ start looking at your Provenge insurance so that we either know yes or no. We just need to know that, Patient: Okay. Doctor: okay, and then we’ll chat about what we see and we’ll get a plan. You’ve heard the kitchen sink now. Now we just have to pick one. Alright, I’ve got to make sure nobody else needs you for anything. Thank you Patient: Alright, thank you. Doctor: as always. Let me know about that leg too. Patient: Yeah. I got to say this only happened probably all that driving.

text: Family Member: But during that whole two years you don’t really know what’s going on because you can’t measure it accurately right?

DOC Because the hormone therapy is suppressing what’s there and killing off ninety nine percent of it, then maybe not that last one percent, maybe, maybe not, the radiation does that. So we’re giving you all that we got. Um hum. Um hum. We want it all. Okay. Um and leakage issue. I think he’s doing pretty good, but how long does that typically take?

DOC About another month or so. A lot of times people get better suddenly. Doctor: So if you’re seeing some improvement it will just continue to get better. Patient: Yeah I was tell G___ you know it when I’m not as active there’s no problem but uh I started work last night so I can definitely feel… Doctor: That’s very common. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: You’re on the right track. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I bet within the month you’re maybe won’t need those pads anymore. Patient: Because the other thing too is uh I coach my daughters softball team so of course get that grade down, a bucket of ball (FAM Laughs) Doctor: So even a year or two from now it’s not gonna be – you don’t have as much resistance to outflow as you used to have. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But it should be enough that you would be dry almost all the time. Patient: Mm, hmm.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Ummm, they compare it to the CAT scan. The CAT scan says there maybe new but more intense. Uh, but bone scans trump CAT scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm, so, we could technically say that that’s stable. Um. They comment more about your jaw this time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: They’re saying that it’s more intense. Uh, and they’re saying this could be more cancer then, you know, dental disease. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. It’s hard to say that because basically a bone scan is just about inflammation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so, if you had dental work or there’s inflammation from troubles related to the Xgeva. That would light up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, if it’s the cancer that’s really causing it, then that, that would cause it to light up. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So what they found is if you give a little bit of prednisone, which is also kind of a hormone, it balances that out. Uh, so we just give a once-a-day low dose, and that seems to be enough to keep the potassium normal. But some people don’t like prednisone. It makes them feel weird. It makes them gain weight. It makes them eat more. Patient: Oh. (Laughter) Doctor: And so, uh, the standard dose was twice a day. We found that if we just give it once a day, it’s enough to counterbalance the thing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so I think either one would be fine. You know? I think choosing either one would be fine. But I think that’s what I would do next is- now, the way I do that is, the other side effect of these drugs are they’re very expensive. So what we do is, uh, we have a whole group here whose job is, if we decide we’re going to do one or the other, I will call them today, and say, “I want to put you on X.” Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They will go and look at your insurance. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Figure out what X is going to cost. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: What’s the best pharmacy to get it from?

text: Patient: Oh. Doctor: And so, this study is looking at a new therapy –uh, the hottest new drugs that are out there, and when we’ve given them to men with prostate cancer, we haven’t seen a whole lot. (Pause) Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Um. And the two drugs together, uh, may be, uh, cause responses. Uh, but we don’t know. And that’s why we’re doing a research study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we’re giving folks who’ve got bad disease this because the worry is these drugs may have a lot of side effects. Most of the time, they’re tolerated well, but what they do is they turn on your immune system, hope that your immune system is going to attack your cancer, but I also could turn on your immune system with these medicines and it attacks you. Okay? So you can get a pneumonia that’s from your immune system. You can get hepatitis because it’s attacking your liver. You could get colitis ‘cuz it’s attacking your colon. Uh, it usually picks one organ, not not all of ‘em, but, you know, you can get into trouble because your immune system – while it’s tryin’ to fight your cancer, it’s tryin’ to fight you. Uh. And when we Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the – Doctor: Both ipilimumab and nivolumab. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: Big words. Patient: Who makes these things up? Doctor: They don’t want us to use -- they want us to use a Yervoy and Opdivo – the shorter ones, but they have big names so if we don’t use them – but I have to use ‘em. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that’s a reasonable study for ya, but you know, again, you would Patient: Screw a weekend, yeah. About an hour and half of life. Doctor: Um. Doctor: The other study that right now, the-the call that I got interrupted was about your eligibility for a phase one study. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
